chapter.title: Using &ostack; Command Line Clients

sect1.title: Managing Networks
sect1.para: Networks can now be managed with the neutron commands, provided by the python-quantumclient package. Alternatively, you can still use the known nova commands, provided by the python-novaclient package.
sect1.sect2:
Creating or Modifying Networks and Subnets &network-def;
&subnet-intro;
&network-role-dependency;
Listing the System Extensions neutron ext-list -c alias -c name
Creating A Network
neutron net-create NETW_NAME
Creates a network for the current project. If you want to specify a network for another project, specify the project's ID with the --tenant-id option. To create a shared network that is accessible to all projects, use the --shared public-net option.
Listing Networks Belonging To a Project
neutron net-list
or neutron net-external-list
Lists the networks (or external networks, respectively) that belong to a project.
Creating a Subnet
neutron subnet-create NETW_NAME_OR_ID NETW_IN_CIDR_NOTATION
For example: neutron subnet-create netw1 10.0.0.0/24
Creates a subnet for the current project. In the example above, the specified network address (10.0.0.0/24) will be associated with the network named netw1.
Creating a Subnet with a Specific Gateway IP
neutron subnet-create --gateway 10.0.0.254 netw1 10.0.0.0/24
Creating a Subnet Without Gateway
neutron subnet-create --no-gateway netw1 10.0.0.0/24
Creating a Subnet with DHCP Disabled
neutron subnet-create netw1 10.0.0.0/24 --enable_dhcp False
Creating a Subnet with a Specific Set of DNS Nameservers
neutron subnet-create netw2 40.0.0.0/24 \ --dns_nameservers list=true 8.8.8.7 8.8.8.8
Creating a Subnet with a Specific Set of Host Routes
neutron subnet-create netw2 40.0.0.0/24 --host_routes \ type=dict list=true destination=40.0.1.0/24,nexthop=40.0.0.2
Creating a Subnet with Multiple Allocation Pools
neutron subnet-create --allocation-pool \ start=192.168.5.31,end=192.168.5.34 netw2 40.0.0.0/24
The --allocation-pool option can be specified multiple times.
Deleting a Network
neutron net-delete NETW_NAME_OR_ID &note-network-delete;
Deleting a Subnet
neutron subnet-delete SUBNET_NAME_OR_ID

Creating or Modifying Ports and Routers &port-dash-automatics;
&port-intro;
As a user, you can only modify certain port attributes. For any other changes, contact your cloud administrator.
Creating A Port
neutron port-create NETW_NAME
Creates a port for the current project and adds it to the specified network. By default, the port will be allocated an available fixed IP address out of one of the designated subnets for each IP version. To specify a certain IP address instead, use the --fixed-ip option as described in the example below.
Creating a Port with Specified IP Address
neutron port-create netw1 --fixed-ip ip_address=192.168.2.40
Creates a port for netw1 with the specified IP address 192.168.2.40.
Listing Ports for a Project
neutron port-list
Th device_owner field in the output describes who owns the port. A port whose device_owner begins with network: is created by &ostack; &netw;. A port whose device_owner begins with compute: is created by &ostack; ∁.
Listing Details for a Port
neutron port-show PORT_ID
&router-intro;
Creating a Router
neutron router-create
Listing Routers for the Current Project
neutron router-list
Deleting a Router
neutron router-delete
Setting the External Network Gateway for a Router
neutron router-gateway-set
Removing an External Network Gateway for a Router
neutron router-gateway-clear
Adding an Internal Network Interface to a Router
neutron router-interface-add
Removing an Internal Network Interface from a Router
neutron router-interface-add

chapter.sect1:
Launching Instances &instances;
When starting an instance, you need to specify the following key parameters:
Flavor
&flavors;
For more details and a list of default flavors available, refer to .
Keypair &keypairs;
For details, refer to .
Security Group &security;
For details, refer to .
Network
Instances can belong to one or multiple networks. By default, each instance is given a fixed IP address, belonging to the internal network.
If needed, you can assign a floating (public) IP address to a running instance and attach a block storage device (volume) for persistent storage. For details, refer to .
Before you can launch an instance, you need to look up a few parameters, for example, which images, flavors, and security groups are available. Proceed as follows:
Launching an Instance
On a shell, source the &ostack; RC file. For details, refer to .
Look up the available flavors:
nova flavor-list
Memorize the ID of the flavor that you want to use for your instance.
Look up the available images:
nova image-list
Memorize the ID of the image that you want to boot your instance from.
Look up the available security groups:
neutron security-group-list
If you have not created any specific security groups, you can only assign the instance to the default security group.
Look up your keypair's name (for SSH access) and memorize it:
nova keypair-list
Now you have all the parameters at hand for starting an instance. Do so with the following command:
nova boot --flavor FLAVOR_ID --imageIMAGE_ID --key_name KEY_NAME \ --security_group NAME_OF_SEC_GROUP NAME_FOR_INSTANCE
The command returns a list of instance properties, including the status of the instance. The status BUILD indicates that the instance has started, but is not yet online.
Check if the instance is online:
nova list
This command lists all instances of the project you belong to, including their ID, their name, their status, and their private (and if assigned, their public) IP addresses. If your instance's status is ACTIVE, the instance is online.
To refine the search, run nova help list to view the available options for the command.
If you did not provide a keypair on starting and have not touched security groups or rules so far, by default the instance can only be accessed from inside the cloud via VNC at this point. Even pinging the instance is not possible. To change this, proceed with .

Configuring Access to the Instances &inst-access-params;
Configuring Security Groups and Rules &security;
Security Groups &sec-groups;
Security groups can now be managed with the neutron security-group* commands, provided by the python-quantumclient package. Alternatively, you can still use the known nova secgroup_*-rule commands, provided by the python-novaclient package.
Listing Security Groups
neutron security-group-list --tenant_id PROJECT_ID
Lists all security groups for the specified project, including the groups' descriptions.
Creating a Security Group
neutron security-group-create SEC_GROUP_NAME GROUP_DESCRIPTION
Creates a new security group with the specified name and description.
Deleting a Security Group
neutron security-group-delete SEC_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID
Deletes the specified group.
&note-groups-delete;
Security Group Rules &sec-rules;
&sec-rules-params;
&security-default;
Configuring Security Group Rules
Security group rules can now be modified with the neutron security-group-rule* commands, available from the python-quantumclient package. Alternatively, you can still use the known nova secgroup_*-rule commands, provided by the python-novaclient package. Proceed as follows:
On a shell, source the &ostack; RC file. For details, refer to .
Look up the existing rules for a security group:
neutron security-group-rule-list SEC_GROUP_NAME taroth 2013-09-03: strange, I could not find any option such as tenant_id or sec_group_name in the options - check!
To enable SSH access to the instances:
Either from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0):
neutron security-group-rule-create --direction ingress \ --protocol tcp --port_range_min 22 --port_range_max 22 \ SEC_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID
Alternatively, you can allow only IP addresses from other security groups (source groups) to access the specified port:
neutron security-group-rule-create --direction ingress \ --protocol tcp --port_range_min 22 --port_range_max 22 \ --remote-group-id SOURCE_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID SEC_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID
To enable pinging the instances:
Either from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0):
neutron security-group-rule-create --protocol icmp --direction ingress SEC_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID
This command allows access to all codes and all types of ICMP traffic, respectively.
Alternatively, you can allow only members of other security groups (source groups) to ping instances:
neutron security-group-rule-create --protocol icmp --direction ingress \ --remote-group-id SOURCE_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID SEC_GROUP_NAME_OR_ID
To allow access via UDP port (for example, for a DNS server running on a VM):
Either from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0):
neutron security-group-rule-create --protocol udp \ --port_range_min 53 --port_range_max 53 --direction ingress \ --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 SEC_GROUP_NAME
Alternatively, you can allow only IP addresses from other security groups (source groups) to access the specified port:
neutron security-group-rule-create --protocol udp \ --port_range_min 53 --port_range_max 53 --direction ingress \ --remote-group-id SOURCE_GROUP_ID_OR_NAME SEC_GROUP_NAME
To delete a security group rule:
neutron security-group-rule-delete SEC_GROUP_ID
Creating or Importing Keys &keypairs;
In case an image uses a static &rootuser; password or a static key set (neither is recommended), you do not need to provide a keypair on starting of the instance.
Creating or Importing Keys
Use the nova keypair-add command to generate a new keypair, or to upload an existing public key.
To generate a new keypair, execute the following commands:
nova keypair-add KEY_NAME > MY_KEY.pem chmod 600 MY_KEY.pem
The first command generates a new keypair named KEY_NAME, writing the private key to the file MY_KEY.pem and registering the public key at the ∁ database. The second command changes the permissions of the file MY_KEY.pem so that only you can read and write to it.
If you already have generated a keypair, with the public key located at ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub, you can upload the public key with the following command:
nova keypair-add --pub_key ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub KEY_NAME
The command registers the public key at the ∁ database and names the keypair KEY_NAME.
Check if the uploaded keypair appears in the list of available keypairs:
nova keypair-list
Managing IP Addresses &ip-addr; &ip-allocate; &ip-assign;
Floating IP addresses can be managed with the neutron commands, provided by the python-quantumclient package. Alternatively, you can still use the known nova commands, provided by the python-novaclient package.
Allocating Floating (Public) IPs to a Project
On a shell, source the &ostack; RC file. For details, refer to .
To find pools that provide floating IPs, list all external networks:
neutron net-list --router:external=True
Among these should be at least one network named floating.
To allocate a floating IP from this pool to the current project:
neutron floatingip-create FLOAT_NETW_ID_OR_NAME
To allocate several floating IPs, repeat the command.
To view the floating IP addresses that have been assigned to the current project, use the following command:
neutron floatingip-list
To release a floating IP from the project, use:
neutron floatingip-delete ID_OF_FLOATING_IP
Assigning Floating (Public) IP Addresses to Instances &ip-assign;
To assign a floating IP to an instance, you need to know both the ID of the floating IP and of the port that has been allocated to the instance.
On a shell, source the &ostack; RC file. For details, refer to .
To find out the port that has been allocated to an instance, proceed as follows:
List all instances of the project you belong to:
nova list
The commands shows the running instances, including their ID, their name, their status, and their private (and if assigned, their public) IP addresses.
Memorize the instance's ID.
Look up the port belonging to the instance ID:
neutron port-list -- device_id INSTANCE_ID
To look up the ID of the floating IP address that you want to assign:
neutron floatingip-list
It lists all floating IPs that belong to the current project, including their ID.
Now you can assign a floating IP to the instance with the following command:
neutron floatingip-associate ID_OF_FLOATING_IP PORT_ID
To check if the floating IP has been assigned, run:
neutron floatingip-show ID_OF_FLOATING_IP
To remove the floating IP address from the instance, use:
neutron floatingip-disassociate ID_OF_FLOATING_IP
